title: This Bacteria Wants to Eat Your Plastic Waste (2021)

transcript.text: This bacteria wants to eat your plastic
[music] waste. My name is Kana and my
partner is Ali. [music] We will be
sharing with you an idea to reduce
microplastics in the ocean to overcome
marine pollution. Most of our waste
including plastics are brought to a
landfill. [music] Some of these plastics
end up in the ocean and they break down
until they form microplastics. [music]
Microplastics are usually different in
shapes and types and they are usually
less than 5 mm in size. Due to this
small size, marine [music] life ends up
consuming this microplastic causing a
lot of bad effects on their health.
[music]
In Japan, scientists discovered a
bacteria that is able to break down
plastic. This bacteria is called [music]
Idinolais.
Many plastics contain polyphilline
teraphilate known as PET. The bacteria
adinola secondis produces [music] two
primary enzymes known as pthase and
methace. These enzymes are able to fully
break [music] down the pet polymer found
in plastics. The breaking down of this
pet [music] polymer produces ethyline
glycol and terafilic acid. These
products are being used by the bacteria
for its own metabolism.
Hey there, [music] it's Ali. Let's talk
about waste water. This is used and
polluted water for mostly human
activities [music] such as from homes
and factories. The waste water is
treated at a waste water treatment
[music] plant before being released into
the ocean or rivers as it has been
considered safe for reuse and for
aquatic life. [music] However, some
developing countries do simply dispose
of untreated waste water into their
rivers and oceans.
Here is an existing wastewater treatment
system. We start from waste water
collection [music] to bar screening to
remove large debris and grit. Next is
the primary clarifier [music]
to remove more solids. Then the aeration
chamber to provide oxygen for bacteria
to break down soluble substances. Next
is the secondary clarifier to remove
[music] any smaller solids through
filters. The last step is chlorination
where all microorganisms are killed off.
The water is [music] then tested before
being released into the environment.
However, microlastics [music] could
still be present after the water is
passed through the aeration chamber.
[music]
Unfortunately, filtration is just not
enough. Microplastics can still be found
even after filtration. The removal of
microplastics [music] is much more
complicated than we'd like to think. The
proper removal of microplastics [music]
need filtration and degradation. And
thus we bring in our plastic [music]
eating bacteria.
And here is our improved waste water
treatment system with the addition of a
dedicated microlastic removal chamber.
Now this chamber will contain our
[music] plastic eating bacteria that

products of these reactions are then

So what happens after [music] chlorine

bacteria. [music]
This ensures our water is free of any
harmful microorganisms [music]
and now our water is clean.
We do have some limitations [music] in

[music] of such treatment plants. The

plastics [music]
and this is the only bacteria in the

And of course, our sustainability
impact. We are reducing the amount of
microlastics [music]
from reaching our oceans and rivers. Two
end products can be reused to make new
PET [music] plastic for industrial

And [music] with that, thanks for
